pros: Working at the Wisconsin Union as part of their production/event support team is a perfect student job, in my opinion. Work is spread out over each shift so you have ample time to work on homework during shifts.
cons: They are not too strict on attendance, which can be a pro or a con depending on which side you fall on. But when you are the only one to show up for a shift and have to complete all of the set-ups yourself, you wish they were a little stricter.

review_title: Great workplace for a college student
pros: Working at the Wisconsin Union as a full-time college student was great. The Union is very understanding and flexible with your class schedule. Being a student supervisor, you will have more responsibilities and expectations to sacrifice time to take care of the building(s).
cons: There haven't been any severely negative things that have happened during my working at the Union. Majority of the staff are students, and everyone gets along well.

pros:

pros: By far, the Wisconsin Union has a great community.  If you're a student looking to work with other college-aged individuals, the environment is second to none. Not only does the work environment facilitate friendships, but your immediate supervisors are also students, which means that they are approachable and forgiving. The work was challenging, but never remedial. Managers consistently have their employees best interest in mind and were easy to communicate with in most situations. Lastly, the customers are great. The Wisconsin Union is excellent because the patrons are jocund and polite (usually)  The views are gorgeous. Everybody has a good time, even the employees have a good time.
cons:
Scheduling can be an absolute pain. I worked mostly in the summer when 40 hours per week is doable. However, many of my co-workers found it difficult to balance a full course load with their workload.  
Operating procedures best practices varied widely from manager to manager, on the whole, this was something that fast improving when I worked here, but it can be challenging to adapt to individual preferences that change by the shift.

pros:
At least in my unit (Prairie Fire):
-Hours are self selected
-it's easy to get shifts covered if you need them for personal stuff, and academic conflicts don't count against you if they don't get covered
-never required to work breaks
-Wages are really quite nice
-recently, our staff has been really social
cons:
Again, for Prairie Fire only:
-Nobody ever gets fired, even when it's really necessary. It's awful because it puts way more stress on the staff that consistently shows up to work than is necessary.
-Can't keep tips, which can't be avoided, but still is kind of annoying
-open hours that are very very slow and boring

job_title: Food Retail Catering Lead in Madison, WI
pros: Excellent hours, excellent help, great work environment, supportive upper level management, a lot of professional development opportunities, excellent benefits, a lot of PTO, flexibility to handle medical concerns if needed.
cons: High turnover so if you do not like training your part time staff or you do not like working with a younger work population I don't recommend working for the Union. College students are most of your workers. I love working with this demographic but be aware that this is a concern if you're not fond of constantly training or experiencing change because your work environment will constantly change to meet the demands of college students. You won't get any raises really; since it is a public institution, this isn't likely to change.

review_title: It really is the best place to work, especially as a student.
pros:
Great student internship - paid, flexible, school-first mentality, friendly and relaxed.

A "learning laboratory" to get a clue of how the "real world" works, encourage you to not be too afraid to screw up.  Also very much about your individual skills advancement and how that can effectively translate into your next step in life.

Extremely friendly coworkers who understand that school/work balance, and are always there for you.
cons: Other paid internships generally have a higher base wage, but raises are still regular (every 6 or so months) enough where it shouldn't deter you.

pros: Good managers and coworkers, however the work environment can vary. Enjoyed my time there however, it was a good summer positions
cons: Pay, and lots of workplace politics. Upper management has no idea about what employees want and what they need. It seems that there is a real disconnect between FT employees and the students working there.

review_title: Rough hours, easy work, fun co-workers, micromanaging.  Great summer job for freshman and sophomores
pros: Conversing with other students can be quite enjoyable.  Your responsibility is minimal.  You typically have days off if you don't mind working nights.
cons: Must work weekends often.  Managers can be over-bearing.  Work can be mind-numbing.  Customer service can be frustrating especially with the high volume of customers.

pros: Very flexible around your school schedule. I worked at a Deli and never had to work nights or weekends. The pay is outstanding for a first job!
cons: Management was frustrating at times since there was little communication over issues the delis were having. Customers could be rude but that's any job in food service.

pros: Schedule works around classes, it's easy to make friends, simple job.
cons: Sometimes it's hard to find people to cover your shifts if you have a conflict (exam, out of town, appointment, etc), and some places make it overwhelming if it's busy and you're understaffed

pros: The Union is an amazing place to work if you want to meet other students while gaining workplace experience. There is an ability to grow and move up in your unit.
cons: Management is very unorganized and often miscommunication is a result of that. The voices of the student employees seem to be lost in the shuffle of management.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: Good wages and low taxes. High flexibility with schedules. In general, good co-workers. Management understands that you're going to be hungover on friday, saturday or sunday mornings, and are mostly nice enough to not yell at you. Free food on the job sometimes!
cons: Training is boring (but always is in food service industry). No tips

review_title: It was a fun time but a lot of work
pros: Everyone is going through the same thing you are going through. There are supports from your supervisors
cons: Hours of work may shift if you put in closing as your end shift. They do not specify.

review_title: Too much pressure for what should be fun company
pros: Fun projects once in a while. You get to see your work all over campus, which is cool for a student graphic designer.
cons: Boss at the time made the environment way too stressful for a student intern, who was working in between classes. Often time, I felt like I was focusing more on my job than school.

review_title: They actually care about their workers
pros: They offer great opportunities and room for growth within each department. They provided hourly employees with a month’s pay for the COVID-19 pandemic.
cons: Starting wages are on the lower side. If in the food & dining department, you do not receive the tips from customers, but the money goes back to dining vouchers and socials for Union employees.

review_title: Great place to work, very friendly staff and environment. Super easy to get the job, basically just apply and will get b
pros: Great place to work, very friendly staff and environment. Super easy to get the job, basically just apply and will get based on availability.
cons: Did not like the management, some employees are very lazy, but overall the students are pretty united

pros: I worked at the Food and Beverage department. The people who work there are very helpful and focus a lot on team work.
cons: When working longer shifts, I wish they can let us have a free meal. Sometimes we are short on staff so it can be very stressful.

pros: Friendly people work here. Lots of students working to pay for college. Free coffee!
cons: Slightly boring at times, but depending on the location and time of day it can be very face-paced.

pros: Lots of opportunities for involvement, flexible, great location, and benefits.
cons: Limited opportunities for advancement, low pay, minimal investment in employee growth and retention. Disorganized administration.

pros: You get to make a lot of friends and good relationships with people you meet, can also build a network of alumni.
cons: No control over schedules, requests for time off is often ignored.
